official-title.#text: To provide legal certainty to property owners along the Red River in Texas, and for other purposes.

action-desc.#text: Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Red River Private Property Protection Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Red River Private Property Protection Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: hereby disclaims any right, title, and interest to all Red River lands located south of the South Bank of the Red River. This Act does not change or affect in any manner the sovereignty rights of federally recognized Indian tribes over lands located to the north of the South Bank of the Red River. Tribal sovereignty rights continue to be established and defined by controlling Federal law.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Claims process and issuance of deeds

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall relinquish, disclaim, and shall transfer by special warranty deed all right, title, and interest of the United States in and to Red River lands to any claimant who demonstrates to the satisfaction of the
that the claimant—

text.#text: The
holds all right, title, and interest under a chain of title for at least 30 years from the time of submission;
has a deed recorded in the appropriate county; and
has paid all taxes assessed on the land and any interest and penalties associated with any period of tax delinquency.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall publish in the Federal Register and on official and appropriate Web sites the process to receive written and/or electronic submissions of the documents required under subsection (a). The
shall treat all proper notifications received from the claimant as fulfilling the satisfaction requirements under subsection (a).

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall accept all official county and State records as filed in the county on the date of submission proving right, title, and interest, including all land accreted to those lands identified by such records by the processes of erosion and accretion.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall approve or disapprove a request for a special warranty deed under subsection (a) not later than 180 days after the date on which the written request is received by the
. If the Secretary fails to approve or disapprove such a request by the end of such 180-day period, the request shall be deemed to be approved.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Time Period for Approval or Disapproval of Request

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: must contain—

text.#text: Any final decision by the
a field note description used to determine the property claim, which must be—
sufficient to locate the land on the ground;
consistent with the claimant’s deed; and
include all land accreted to the claimant by the processes of erosion and accretion;
an accurate plat of the land that is—
consistent with the field notes; and
prepared by a Texas licensed State land surveyor; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: considers appropriate consistent with the provisions and intent of this Act.

text.#text: any other matters required by law or as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall establish procedures for an administrative hearing—

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: regarding a claim by
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Red River Private Property Protection Act/s:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to the claimant’s property; and

text.#text: for a claimant to appeal the final decision made pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Red River Private Property Protection Act/s:3

text.#text: to adjudicate disputes between two or more private property owners who have interest claims that overlap pursuant to documents submitted under

If after the final determination has been issued under subsection (a) and the private property owner disputes the decision, the private property owner may pursue a claim in a Federal district court within the State of Texas.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that no parcels of Red River lands are treated as Federal land for the purpose of any resource management plan until the
has ensured that such parcels are not subject to transfer under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Red River Private Property Protection Act/s:3

text.#text: The
Nothing in this Act shall alter—
any present or future rights and interests of the Kiowa, Comanche, and Apache Tribes and their members or Indian successors-in interest;
any tribal trust lands;
allotted lands that may be held in trust or lands subject to a Federal restriction against alienation;
any boundaries of lands owned by the tribes referred to in paragraph (1), including lands referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), pursuant to the gradient boundary survey method; and

the sovereign rights, jurisdiction, or other governmental interests of the Kiowa, Comanche, and Apache Tribes and their members or Indian successors-in interest existing or which may be acknowledged by Federal and tribal law.

header.#text: Sale of remaining red river surface rights

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has ensured that Red River lands parcels are not subject to transfer under
, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Red River Private Property Protection Act/s:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall offer any and all such remaining identified Federal lands for disposal by competitive sale for not less than fair market value as determined by an appraisal conducted in accordance with nationally recognized appraisal standards, including the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions; and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice.

text.#text: After the

header.#text: Competitive sale of identified Federal lands

text.#text: The sale of identified Federal lands under this section shall be subject to valid existing tribal, State, and local rights.
Net proceeds from the sale of identified Federal lands under this section shall be used to offset any costs associated with this Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to the
and the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a list of any identified Federal lands that have not been sold under subsection (a) and the reasons such lands were not sold.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate

text.#text: Not later than 5 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
For the purposes of this Act—

term.#tail: means lands along the approximately 116-mile stretch of the Red River from its confluence with the North Fork of the Red River on the west to the 98th meridian on the east between the States of Texas and Oklahoma;

text.#text: the term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , acting through the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of Bureau of Land Management

text.#text: the term

quote.#tail: means the water-washed and relatively permanent elevation or acclivity, commonly called a cut bank, along the southerly or right side of the Red River which separates its bed from the adjacent upland, whether valley or hill, and usually serves to confine the waters within the bed and to preserve the course of the river; as specified in the fifth paragraph of the decree rendered March 12, 1923, in

text.#text: the term

quote.#tail: means the measurement technique used to demarcate a division of ownership or jurisdiction along the South Bank under the methodology established by the

text.#text: the term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: which recognizes that the boundary line between the States of Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River is subject to such changes as have been or may be wrought by the natural and gradual processes known as erosion and accretion as specified in the second, third, and fourth paragraphs of the decree rendered March 12, 1923, in
